question: Is the type of evidence a document?
Is the type of evidence from a witness?
Yes, the evidence is a document per s 47 (definitions) of the EA
Then it is not admissible
Is the witness competent? - Section 13 of the Evidence Act
Is the witness compellable?- Section 14 of the Evidence Act
Is there absoluetly no capacity? - Section 13 EA
A person can’t give evidence if they can’t understand questions or give understandable answers, and that can’t be fixed.- Section 13(1)(a) and (b)
Next Threshold!
Therefore, the witness does not have the capacity to be a witness ( as per section 14) or is a sovereign of the state (as per section section 15)
Is there some capacity- in that the witness is able to give evidence to some facts and not give evidence to others (S 13 2)
Is the document avaliable?( Use Part 2 of the dictionary, Clause 5)
A person who is incapacitated can give either unsworn evidence(S 13(3)) or give sworn evidence to parts of the evidence (S 13(2)
Therefore, the document can be admitted.
Would there be substantial cost delay in ensuring that the witness has capacity with provisions?(S 14(a)
Under section 14(a)- the witness would not be compellable to give evidence
Is the evidence that is required to be provided unncessary in that other people may be able to give such evidence ( S 14(2))
Under section 14(b)- the witness would not be compellable to give evidence
Under section 14- the witness would be compelled to provide the evidence
Take a second to note your fact in issue (FIS) if you ignored it before.

Is your evidence related to the credibility of witnesses (s 55(2)(a)) or 
admissibility of the evidence (s 55(2)(b)), or
 a failure to adduce evidence (s 55(2)(c))?
Therefore, evidence is taken to be relevant
Is your evidence rationally (directly or indirectly) affecting the assessment of the probablity of the existence of a FIS as per Section 55?
Therefore it is relevant.
Therefore is not relevant.
Next Threshold!
Therefore evidence is not admissible

The Credibility rule is when the evidence speak to the credibility of a witness in the proceedings (per EA s 102). If it does apply, then the Evidence is not admissible UNLESS exceptions apply as show in the next question.

Is the evidence being used to attack the credibility of an opposing witness (EA s103)? OR
Is the evidence being used to rebut a representation that was later denied (EA s 103)? OR
Is the evidence being used by a party to bolster the credibility of their own witness (EA s 108)

The evidence is likely admissible for a credibility use. NB: there may be further implications to note if an opposing witness is being cross-examined (see EA s 103), or if they are attacking the credibility of a party’s own witness (see EA s 108A). We encourage you to explore these.
It is likely that it is not admissable
Does the Opinion rule apply per EA s 76? IE, is the evidence an inference drawn from observed and communicable facts or data, as defined in Lithgow City Council v Jackson [2011]?

The evidence is likely not admissible per s 76 opinion rule, where evidence of an opinion is not admissible to prove the existence of a fact about the existence of which the opinion was expressed, UNLESS exceptions can be applied (Click Ok to see exceptions)
Next Section!( Click ok to move to the next section)
Is the evidence collaterally accepted with another threshold?
The evidence can be used collaterally with the other use as opinion use
The evidence is not admissible for a collateral opinion use BUT may be applicable to a different exception to the opinion rule.

Is the evidence a lay opinion? IE, is the opinion based on:
a) What the witness saw or otherwise perceived; and 
b) Is the evidence of the opinion necessary to obtain an adequate understanding of the person’s perception of a matter or event per EA s 78?
The evidence is admissible for s 78 lay opinion use as an exception to the s 76 opinion rule
The evidence is admissible for s 78 lay opinion use as an exception to the s 76 opinion rule
Could the opinion be an expert opinion, IE, is it an opinion based on specialised knowledge per EA s 79?

Keep in mind, there are 3 thresholds that must be satisfied. Does the opinion evidence satisfy EACH OF the following?
 1) there is specialised knowledge to be applied to this issue (refer to Smith v The Queen (2001), R v Hien Puoc Tang [2006]); AND
2)The expert has acquired the knowledge through training, study, or experience (remember ‘ad hoc’ experts exist, and refer to R v Leung and Wong (1999)); AND
3)The opinion is wholly or substantially based on that ‘knowledge’.
Likely not admissible.
Likely admissible for specialised opinion evidence use as an exception to the s 76 opinion rule.
It is an admission. The hearsay rule and the opinion rule does not apply.(Section 81)
It is not an admission. The hearsay rule and the opinion rule does apply.(Section 82)
Was there a statement made by a person who is or becomes a party to a proceeding(defendant/party) and is it against the interest of the parties (Part 1: Definitions of the EA).

Is the evidence of the Statement being made first hand in that: A) Was the evidence of the statement given by a person who witnesses the admission being made first hand or, B)Was the admission made by a document?
Does the admission used to affect the case of a third party OR against a third party?

Section 83(1) of the Evidence Act – Hearsay and Opinion Rule Exceptions
The hearsay rule and the opinion rule may apply, unless the following condition is met:
Section 83(2): The third party consents to the statement being used as evidence.
  • Note: Consent must be given for the entire evidence, not just a portion.Section 83(4)

Was the Admission influenced by conduct which may be characterised as violent,opressive, inhuman/degrading/coercive or threatening?(S 84(1)(a)(b)) [Only go through this if it is a raised issue in the proceedings (S 84(2))]
Section 84 applies → Admission not admissible
In A CRIMINAL PROCEEDING ONLY: was an oral admission made by the defendant to an investigating official OR in response to a question/representation?
Was the oral admission made in circumstances where the truth of the admission was likely unaffected?
It is an admission. The hearsay rule and the opinion rule does not apply.(Section 81) However, the courts may choose to refuse to admit the admission ( Press Ok for that test)
Is the evidence presented by the prosecution (S 90(a))
Would admitting the evidence be unfair to the defendant based on teh circumstances of the admission?
Courts may refuse to admit the full or partial admission
Evidence may be admitted.
It is admissible!
It is not admissible.
NB: the tendency and coincidence uses of evidence are extremely contentious in terms of jurisprudential and ethical debates. There is no black and white pathway or answer.
Does the evidence fall under the tendency or coincidence rule?

Is your evidence a tendency (rather than a coincidence), where the evidence is of the character, reputation or conduct of a person, or a tendency that a person has or had and is therefore not admissible, per EA s 97?
The evidence is likely not admissible, unless the following exceptions apply (or will be applied).

Do the following exceptions apply to the evidence?
a)The party seeking to adduce the evidence gives reasonable notice in writing to the other party of the party’s intention to adduce the evidence; and
b)the court thinks that the evidence will, either by itself or having regard to other evidence, have significant probative value.

The evidence is likely admissible due to an exception to the s 97 Tendency rule.  NB: Special thresholds may apply to criminal matters if evidence is adduced by the prosecution. Refer to EA s 101. You may then refer to key cases, Pfennig v The Queen (1995) and R v Ellis [2003], in your answer/notes. These are not covered in this database as they require your own individually worded critique and analysis of the issues.

Then is your evidence a coincidence, where evidence that two or more things happened is used to prove that someone did something or felt a certain way, just because the events were similar and it seems unlikely they were a coincidence? And it is therefore not admissible per EA s 98?
The evidence is likely not admissible, unless the following exceptions apply (or will be applied),

Do the following exceptions apply to the evidence?
a)The party seeking to adduce the evidence gives reasonable notice in writing to the other party of the party’s intention to adduce the evidence; and
b)the court thinks that the evidence will, either by itself or having regard to other evidence, have significant probative value.

The evidence is likely admissible due to an exception to the s 98 Coincedence rule.  NB: Special thresholds may apply to criminal matters if evidence is adduced by the prosecution. Refer to EA s 101. You may then refer to key cases, Pfennig v The Queen (1995) and R v Ellis [2003], in your answer/notes. These are not covered in this database as they require your own individually worded critique and analysis of the issues.
Your evidence is not a tendency or a coincidence. Try a different threshold.
Next Section!

Before analysing the admissibility of hearsay evidence, note the following:
a) What is the asserted fact/previous representation? (also ensure this is relevant to the fact in issue, identify if this is ‘first hand hearsay’ per s 62)
b) Who is the maker?

Also note that notices and objections to admitting evidence for a hearsay use per s 67 and s 68 are not covered in this portion of the database ,but you may like to refer to them.
Does the rule against hearsay apply to the evidence, IE is the evidence a previous representation made by a person per EA s 59 being used to prove an asserted fact?

The evidence is likely not admissible, unless it is used collaterally with another use, or if an exception applies (such as admissions, covered later). Proceed with the hearsay checklist to see how it can still be admissible.
The evidence is likely not hearsay and therefore is admissable
Are we in civil proceedings?
Is the maker available? IE, they are not dead, they are competent, they can lawfully provide the evidence per EA definitions part 2 s 4.
Are we in Criminal Proceedings?
Is the maker available?

The hearsay rule does not apply to evidence in civil proceedings where:
 the maker is available and;
it would cause undue expense or undue delay, 
or would not be reasonably practicable to call the person who made the representation to give evidence per s 64. If these conditions are satisfied, Click Yes. Otherwise Click No.

The hearsay rule does not apply to evidence in civil proceedings where the maker is unavailable, or a document if it contains the representation and you can understand the representation just from the document.If these conditions are satisfied, Click Yes. Otherwise Click No.

The hearsay rule does not apply to evidence in criminal proceedings where the maker is available and the occurrence of the asserted fact was fresh in the memory per s 66. ‘Fresh in the memory’ per s 66(2A) considers:
a)the nature of the event concerned; and
b)the age and health of the person; and
c)the period of time between the occurrence of the asserted fact and the making of the representation.If these conditions are satisfied, Click Yes. Otherwise Click No.

The hearsay rule does not apply to evidence in criminal proceedings where the maker is unavailable, or a document if it contains the representation and you can understand the representation just from the document.If these conditions are satisfied, Click Yes. Otherwise Click No.
Error: you need to be in either criminal or civil proceedings.
The evidence is likely hearsay and therefore is not admissable
Next Section!
These are discretionary exclusions. Use this sections to assess whether the court would admit the evidence or not.

Is the probative value substantially outweighed by the risk that the evidence:
(a) May be unfairly prejudicial to a party OR
(b) May mislead or confuse the court OR
(c) Is a waste of time? [ Section 135]
It is not admissible.

Is the probative value substantially outweighed by risk that the evidence:
(a) May be unfairly prejudicial to a party OR
(b) May mislead or confuse the court [Section 136]
Is it a criminal proceeding?

(Section 137):
Is the probative value outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice to the defendant?
It is most likely admissible
